content should not be in your local database or on your Local Pages because they're going to go through versioning and updates from other teams at your
company marketing teams usually and they need access to it and they need their own rules wrapped around it and they

um in the good old days of working with Spa applications what would happen is you'd have this big fat wad of
JavaScript and everything get compiled down into one single JS file including the HTML and all the templating and be
jammed down to the client and you get a bunch of spinners on the page as everything took its time loading up and
you'd overload the browser memory and everything would crash so what we do nowadays with these build
tools like webpack and Veet is that it will split that JavaScript out per route
if you have a multi-page application it'll optimize it so that what you get is just in time scripting from the
browser so that makes everything nice asp.net does not do that and this is an
interesting thing because again we're coming back now to we have two applications running it just so happens that asp.net plays very nice with Veet
